topic.title: Port Partition P2P Binding Command

body.p: The Port Partition P2P Binding Command is used to dynamically bind physical ports to logical bridge binding instances in the switch.

It has four sub-commands:
Bind Port
Unbind Port
Port Binding Info
Partition Binding Info

table.title: MRPC Dynamic Partition Command Input Data
MRPC Port Partition P2P Binding Command Input Data

body.p:
The sub command codes:
0x0 - Bind Port
0x1 - Unbind Port
0x2 - Port Binding Info
0x3 - Partition Binding Info
All others reserved
These arguments change depending on the sub command, as given in the table below.

table.title: Port Partition P2P Binding Command Return Values

row.entry: Logical Bridge Binding Instance Already Bound
Logical Bridge Binding Instance Not Bound To Physical Port

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic struct-d) (topic firmware-d) (topic pmcrevhis-d)
topic.title: Port Partition P2P Binding—Bind Port Sub-Command

section.p: The Bind Port sub-command is used to trigger a binding operation. This will bind the physical port to a logical bridge binding instance in a partition and simulate a Hotplug event if the slot supports Hotplug related events reporting. After the binding operation, Switchtec sends an asynchronous notification to the requester.
The ID of the partition to which the logical bridge binding instance belongs. Valid values are '0' to 'number of partitions - 1'
The ID of the logical bridge instance to which the physical port will be bound. ID '0' is always the ID of the USP. Valid values are from '1' to 'number of DSP'.
The ID of the physical port. Valid values are from '0' to '47'. The corresponding physical port must not be bound to any other logical bridge binding instance.
There is no output data for this sub-command.

li.p: Link the physical port to the logical P2P bridge. Once this is done, the link-related hardware can be configured through the logical P2P bridge.
Inform the OS of the Hotplug event so that the OS enumerates the attached device.

The binding procedure depends on the slot capability of the P2P bridge/physical slot. If the attention button and power LED are implemented, the switch will simulate an attention event and will wait for the power-LED-on control operation from the OS. If only a PRESENT signal is available on the slot, the switch treats the link up event as indication of a successful bind command. If no success indication event occurs, the bind command eventually times out, and the command is marked as a failure. Users can use a port/partition query sub-command to obtain the command result when the bind/unbind finish port event occurs. The timeout period is 9 seconds. If management Hotplug slot events are defined on the slot, typically the OS takes 4-5 seconds to set the POWER CONTROL on and turn the POWER LED on. User could trigger multiple bind/unbind commands simultaneously as long as the target physical/logical port is not the same. If the slot only supports a PRESENT event, the OS will enumerate the attached device within 1s.

section.p: All the return codes listed above are subject to this bind sub-command. If a port is already unbound and a request is made to unbind it again, MRPC will return 0x0000000B.

If port bind checking failed, one error return code will be generated to inform caller of why the physical port cannot be bound to the logical P2P port. Please check the following table for more detail of the error code.

strow.stentry: Partition Address Routing Resource checking failed
Partition Address Translation Resource checking failed
Partition ID Resource checking failed
Partition NT LUT Resource checking failed
Partition NT Configuration Resource checking failed
Partition Implicit Resource checking failed
PFF (PCIe Function Framework) Instance ID checking failed
No PCIe Physical Port Existing Specified By Physical Port ID
The Physical Port does not have Attention Button defined on its Slot while the Logical Port Slot Capability does have the Attention Button.
The Physical Port does not have Power Control defined on its Slot while the Logical Port Slot Capability does have Power Control defined.
The Physical Port does not have Manual Retention Latch defined on its Slot while the Logical Port Slot Capability does have Manual Retention Latch defined.
The Physical Port does not have Attention LED defined on its Slot while Logical Port Slot Capability does have Attention LED defined.
The Physical Port does not have Power Led defined in its Slot while the Logical Port Slot Capability does have Power Led defined.
NT Resource checking failed.
PCIe Link Capability check, no physical port found.
PCIe Link Capability check, physical port Link Rate does not match the one defined in logical P2P port.

section.p: Bind physical port 0x20 to the third DSP of partition 4 using the UART interface.

strow.stentry: Write Bind MRPC CMD to MRPC command register
Trigger MRPC CMD No.12 (port binding/unbinding command)
Read MRPC CMD return code

section.p: If the MRPC CMD return code is 0, all the parameters are valid and the bind mrpc cmd has been accepted by switch.

Firmware might spend at most 12s to finish the accepted Bind command. Before the Bind command finishes, user cannot trigger another Port Bind operation to the same physical port, otherwise, Return Code - Bind/Unbind In Progress will be returned.

After Bind MRPC command is accepted by Firmware, users need to use another MRPC command (Port Binding Info) to check status of the submitted Bind command. Port Binding Info MRPC command uses physical port ID as the query index. This Info query MRPC command returns three status, SUCCEEDED/FAILED/IN PROGRESS. Both SUCCEEDED and FAILED indicate the MRPC command has finished and user can trigger another Bind/Unbind command to that physical port. If user get return code of IN PROGRESS, the command has not finished yet and users need to check status later again.
For the detailed information on Port Binding Info command, see the following command description.
section.note: Logical bridge ID defines the logical P2P bridge index within a partition. The logical port index of the switch upstream port is 0. The indexes of the downstream switch ports range from 1 to N-1, where N stands for the total number of P2P bridges within a specific partition.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic struct-d) (topic firmware-d) (topic pmcrevhis-d)
topic.title: Port Partition P2P Binding—Unbind Port Sub-Command

section.p: The Unbind Port sub-command is used to trigger an unbinding operation. This simulates a Hot-Remove event and unbind the physical port from the logical bridge binding instance of a partition after the Hot-Remove has finished. After the unbind operation is complete, Switchtec sends an asynchronous notification to the requester. See
for details on the unbind operation.

table.title: MRPC Unbind Port Command Input Data

section.p: The ID of the partition to which the logical bridge binding instance belongs. Valid values are '0' to 'number of partitions - 1'
The ID of the logical bridge binding instance to which the physical port will be bound. ID '0' is always the ID of the USP. Valid values are from '1' to 'number of DSP'.
Options for the unbinding operation:

ul.li: 0x0 - Unbind the physical port from the logical bridge binding instance when the physical link is down. If the link is up, do not unbind the port.
0x1 - If the link of the physical port is in L0 or L1, simulate a Managed Hot-Remove first. The physical port will not be unbound until the physical link is down.
0x2 - If the link of the physical port is in L0 or L1, simulate a Surprise Hot-Remove first. The physical port will not be unbound until the physical link is down.

0x3 - If the link of the physical port is in L0 or L1, simulate a Surprise Link Down first. The physical port will not be unbound until the physical link is down. For more information on Surprise Link Down errors, see PCIe Error Handling.

section.p: There is no output data for this sub-command.
All the return codes listed above are subject to this bind sub-command except for 0x00000001, 0x00000002, 0x0000000A, 0x0000000C.

The unbind sequence depends on both the unbind option and the type of slot defined by the P2P bridge slot capability. Before unbinding the physical port from the P2P bridge, the switch will generate a P2P-supported PCIe Hotplug event to inform the OS of Hotplug events. If the P2P bridge supports management Hotplug, the OS will use the management Hotplug protocol to take power control. The switch will check the logical P2P bridge's slot capability and simulate supported Hotplug events. Similarly to a bind operation, the switch will maintain a 9-second timer to track this unbinding procedure. If the unbind operation is finished, the corresponding port will generate one bind/unbind event. The user could also query the port/partition status through an MRPC sub command. If the slot supports management Hotplug events, typically the OS takes 4-5 seconds to complete the bind operation. If the slot only supports the PRESENT event, the OS will accept the bind operation within 1 second.
Use the management option to unbind the physical port on logical P2P bridge 6 of partition 2 using the UART interface.

strow.stentry: Write Unbind MRPC CMD to MRPC command register
Trigger MRPC CMD No.12 (port binding/unbinding command)
Read MRPC CMD return code

section.p: If the MRPC CMD return code is 0, all the parameters are valid and the unbind mrpc cmd has been accepted by switch.

Firmware might spend at most 12s to finish the accepted Unbind command. Before the unbind command finishes, user cannot trigger another Port Bind/Unbind operation to the same physical port, otherwise, Return Code - Bind/Unbind In Progress will be returned.

After Unbind MRPC command is accepted by Firmware, users need to use another MRPC command (Port Binding Info) to check status of the submitted Unbind command. Port Binding Info MRPC command uses physical port ID as the query index. This Info query MRPC command returns three status, SUCCEEDED/FAILED/IN PROGRESS. Both SUCCEEDED and FAILED indicate the MRPC command has finished and user could trigger another Bind/Unbind command to that physical port. If user get return code of IN PROGRESS, the command has not finished yet and users need to check status later again.
For the detailed information on Port Binding Info command , refer to the following command description.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic struct-d) (topic firmware-d) (topic pmcrevhis-d)
topic.title: Port Partition P2P Binding—Port Binding Info Sub-Command

section.p: The Port Binding Info sub-command is used to query the port binding information. The results of binding and unbinding operations are returned in the output data and grouped by physical port. This information can be queried at any time.

table.title: Port Binding Info Command Input Data
Port Binding Info Command Input Data

section.p: The ID of the physical port to query.
If 0xFF is specified, then the status of all the enabled physical ports will be queried.

table.title: Port Binding Info Command Output Data
Port Binding Info Command Output Data

section.p: The returned information entry count. Output DW [0x4:0x4*Info Count] will contain valid data.
The ID of the physical port. Valid values are from '0' to '47'.
The ID of the partition to which the physical port is bound. '0xFF' means the port is not bound to any partition.
The ID of the logical bridge binding instance to which the physical port is bound. '0xFF' means the port is not bound to any logical bridge binding instance.

ul.li:
Bits[0:3]: Operation Results (not updated until a new operation is triggered)
0x0 - Success/ Initial Value
0x1 - Failed
0x2 - In Progress

Bits[4:7]: Binding State (whether the physical port is bound or not)
0x0 - Unbound
0x1 - Bound

section.p: Return code valid for this sub-command:
1. List physical port information for port number 0x20

strow.stentry: Write Port Information Query MRPC CMD to MRPC command register
Trigger MRPC CMD No. 12 (port binding/unbinding command)
Read MRPC CMD return code
Get Port Information from MRPC output register space

section.p: 2. List all physical port information:

strow.stentry: Write Port Information Query MRPC CMD to MRPC command register
Trigger MRPC CMD No. 12 (port binding/unbinding command)
Read MRPC CMD return code
Get Port Information from MRPC output register space

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic struct-d) (topic firmware-d) (topic pmcrevhis-d)
topic.title: Port Partition P2P Binding—Partition Binding Info Sub-Command

section.p: The Partition Binding Info sub-command is used to query the partition binding information. The results of binding and unbinding operations are returned in the output data and grouped by partition. This information can be queried at any time.

table.title: Partition Binding Info Command Input Data
Partition Binding Info Command Input Data

section.p: The ID of the partition to query. Value can range from '0' to '47'.

table.title: Partition Binding Info Command Output Data
Partition Binding Info Command Output Data

section.p: Each logical bridge binding instance of the partition has two bytes indicating the binding information. The ID of the physical port indicates which physical port is bound to the logical bridge binding instance. Valid values are from '0' to '47'. '0xFF' means the logical bridge binding instance has no physical port bound to it.

ul.li:
Bits[0:3]: Operation Results (not updated until a new operation is triggered)
0x0 - Success/ Initial Value
0x1 - Failed
0x2 - In Progress

Bits[4:7]: Binding State (whether the physical port is bound or not)
0x0 - Unbound
0x1 - Bound

section.p: Return code valid for this sub-command:
List physical port binding information for a specified partition.

strow.stentry: Write Port Information Query MRPC CMD to MRPC command register.
Trigger MRPC CMD No. 12 (port binding/unbinding command).
Read MRPC CMD return code.
Get Port Information from MRPC output register space.
